ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In-person lab with one instructor that Zoomed in when it was his week and one instructor that was there in-person every week. Two TAs were also there in-person each week.
Pre-lab content was provided as a live virtual lecture. Professor Wyman attended lab session virtually through a projected screen.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned electrophysiology techniques, analysis of brain anatomy, and how to think like a neurobiologist. We also learned how to utilize different equipment such as an oscilloscope, amplifier, and microelectrodes.
What dissections and other neuroscience techniques are supposed to look like.

I learned to explore concepts in neurobiology, such as action potentials and synaptic modulation, through hands-on experiments involving classic neurobiology model organisms, including such as worms and fruit flies.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Keshishian is a wonderful instructor who has created a thorough and detailed lab course. That being said, there were times when the experiments would not work, but he ensured that we understood the material before we left class.

The experiments never worked and the professor was always left while we were doing them so we were never able to make it work. The TAs tried to help but also couldn't figure out what was wrong/how to make it work so we were all there confused.
Very difficult to get everything done in the time we were given for lab

The course was extremely hands-on and the experiments each week were interesting. I enjoyed being able to refine certain techniques, such as excising a muscle and nerve out of a frog leg, across multiple weeks. The hand outs and pre-lab sessions were detailed and provided good guidance for each lab. This course could be improved by having more TAs around to help troubleshoot experiments--troubleshooting was a necessity in every week, because puzzling outcome (e.g. no readout on the oscilloscope when measuring action potentials) were frequent.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a wonderful environment for learning during the pandemic as there was a low teacher-student ratio, and although we were all in our own separate lab benches, we had a collaborative experience.
We were well-distanced and always had face masks on. Used gloves fairly often too and wore our lab coats so it felt pretty safe.

Moving the pre-lab session to Mondays and providing it in a recorded, virtual format was helpful. In lectures, I think that the inclusion of Prof. Wyman through Zoom was convenient but flawed, as there was no way to communicate directly with him, which slowed down those lab session. However, I understood that there was no better practical way to include him.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Especially if you are a neuroscience major interested in having hands-on experience with electrophysiology techniques.

This class is low workload but very frustrating. If you're comfortable spending 4 hours a week doing essentially nothing then go for it, again it's not that stressful it just feels like you're time is being wasted. The experiments would be cool in theory, but only the professor really ever gets them to work. After his demo, he would leave and not come back for 2 hours and then when he's back he helps 1-2 students and then we all leave. Grading is also very unclear, especially this semester since we didn't have quizzes. Better than other labs in terms of difficulty/time spent out of class, but still annoying.

I would recommend this course to a student taking neurobiology lab if they want some engaging, hands-on material to complement the content of the neurobiology lecture (MCDB 320). The experiments were surprisingly interesting, engaging, and useful, but they came with a high degree of troubleshooting in order to work. This course provides an interesting perspective on neurobiology but will require you to have the time and patience to handle unexpected challenges in lab each week.
